title: 113_hr4894
content: The Act may be cited as the "United States Commission on an Open Society with Security Act of 2014". Congress finds that an open society with free access to public spaces and open discussion is crucial for American democratic values. The United States faces a unique challenge to public safety, requiring the best expertise to address without compromising democratic principles. A commission of experts from various backgrounds is needed to examine factors for securing public safety from terrorist threats while upholding democratic ideals. The United States aims to protect public safety from terrorist attacks while ensuring free and open access to the public. SEC. 3. ESTABLISHMENT OF COMMISSION. The United States Commission on an Open Society with Security is established with 21 members representing various fields. The President appoints a Chairperson from among the members. Members serve for the life of the Commission, with nine members needed for a quorum. The Commission on an Open Society with Security consists of 21 members appointed by various officials. A quorum requires nine members, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission on an Open Society with Security consists of 21 members appointed by various officials. After 90 days of enactment, if 9 or more members are appointed, the Chairperson can start the Commission's operations, including staff hiring. The Commission on an Open Society with Security has functions outlined in Section 4. The Commission will study security and public access to Federal buildings and property. They will examine security practices, building design, public space management, and counterterrorism needs. The impact of public access on security, safety, and free speech will also be considered. The Commission will study security practices, building design, public space management, and counterterrorism needs. They will consider the impact of public access on security, safety, free speech, economies, physical changes, traffic, congestion, job performance, technology use, comparisons with other entities, and analytical methods for assessing terrorism risks. The Commission will coordinate activities to avoid duplication of efforts by others. The Commission has powers to coordinate activities and avoid duplication of efforts by others. The Commission, its members, or agents can hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. They can obtain necessary information from US government entities. Commission members and staff must have security clearances for access to classified materials. The Commission or its staff must have security clearances and follow security protocols to access classified records and materials from government agencies. Members of the Commission and its staff must have security clearances and follow protocols to access classified records. They are restricted from using acquired information for nonofficial purposes and must have a need-to-know basis for accessing such materials. The Commission may use the United States mails, accept gifts, and receive administrative support services on a reimbursable basis. SEC. 6. PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission will not receive compensation for their service. They will be reimbursed for travel expenses at authorized rates. The Chairperson has the authority to appoint staff without following certain regulations. The Commission can appoint a director and necessary personnel, with pay not exceeding GS-15 rates. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Chairperson can hire experts and consultants at rates not exceeding GS-15 pay. The Commission will submit a final report to the President within 2 years of its initial meeting, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The President must then transmit the report to Congress within 6 months, along with any comments or recommendations. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting the final report. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations for the Act includes $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2015 and $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2016.
